assets.caption: Above Tagert Hut
Above Tagert Hut

description: Above Tagert hut.  Saturday night 1-2 inches of graupel. Surface freezing Thursday night to Sunday night. Low at Tagert hut has been around 32 degrees F.

assets.caption: View after cutting across the roll and flushing the problematic face out.

route: Mountain Boy Peak NE Face from Graham Gulch.
description:
We were a party of four shortly behind the skier that also submitted their observation (https://avalanche.state.co.us/observations/field-report/634b27f1-d8f1-4b1b-8a53-b33c87ad1734) of a skier triggered wet slide on Mountain Boy Peak today. We skied the same line and flushed everything out that their smaller slide left behind. Sopping wet snow slid on the dust layer. I suspect that it did not freeze last night. Total mass of snow that moved was likely D2, but it was intentionally released by three of us in succeeding slides. So maybe D1-1.5?

Also, that cornice up top on the more easterly aspect is about to go. It was sagging hard and shedding microwave size chunks off every 5-20 minutes today while we were up there.

assets.caption: Dragontail & Dead Elk
Corral Couloir
Cornice Fall
Cornice above Corral Couloir

route: We approached Flattop Mountain via Flattop Mountain trail from the Bear Lake Trailhead.  We skied Tyndall Glacier/Headwall back to Bear lake, via Tyndall Gorge.
description:
Avy Obs: >TL - ENE - C - N - R1 - D2  (Cornice Fall on Tyndall Headwall, Likley from 5/19)

Weather Obs:
9:00am @ 12,200' East Aspect
Sky: SCT
Wind: Moderate, West 
Ski Pen: 1cm

12:00pm @ 11,000' ENW Aspect
Sky: BKN
Wind: Light, West
Snow Conditions: Iso, Lots of snow moving (WL) on NTL, all aspects.
Wet slab approximately 3-6cm deep, D2 size triggered by a skier in our party in crooked couloir at approximately 1:30pm.

assets.caption: Zoomed in on slide. Wonderful picture of course
E face of cathedral, crown and path visible in top middle.

route: Ascended couloir on e face of cathedral, noticed ice crust and lack of bonding between new snow (dusting) and dust layer, as well as rotten snow quite deep in the snowpack at times. Discussed a few different times, and continued with plan. Summited about 930 (too late, took us forever) dropped E face and after 3rd turn, I dropped 6' in awful snow behind a rock and simultaneously popped a wet slab about 5' deep and 10' wide. Slide ran down the face picking up all snow in its path for 200' then poured over rocks underneath and down into basin 1200' below.
description:
Awful unconsolidated snow all over. Ice crust wet slab problem should be concerning to travelers in the central/elks right now. Discussions in basin included- 
- Very little snow in elks Last night (5/19-5/20)  
-guessed  the peaks were socked in and might not have gotten proper freeze. 
-e face is not the aspect at this time of year 
- dust crust and unsupportive base snow are resulting in wumphing but because of wet slab, not p slab (but still strong/weak) 

Lucky to just have the poo scared out of me. Could have ended up lot worse

avalanche_observations.comments: Small wet slab pulled out as the avalanche ran

avalanche_detail.description: I descended a steep east face and pushed snow down in front of me triggering a loose wet avalanche. As the avalanche ran it pulled out a thin wet slab. This was mostly the recent crust sliding on top of the dust layer. After triggering this slide I stayed near the bed surface as i am quite certain I could have triggered additional avalanches The avalanche was on an east-facing slope at 12,800 ft.

I descended a steep east face and pushed snow down in front of me triggering a loose wet avalanche. As the avalanche ran it pulled out a thin wet slab. This was mostly the recent crust sliding on top of the dust layer. After triggering this slide I stayed near the bed surface as i am quite certain I could have triggered additional avalanches The avalanche was on an east-facing slope at 12,800 ft.

weather_detail.description: Mostly cloudy, light winds, above freezing temps. Clouds were less up canyon than down near Twin Lakes, though it seemed like darker clouds were moving in from the west when I descended at around 9:30 AM.

assets.caption: Debris from a small skier triggered wet avalanche on an east-facing above-treeline slope.
This is where the loose wet avalanche pulled out as a very thin slab.
The snow surface was frozen with a 2 to 4 cm crust but the crust was not strong. It quickly broke down in the morning hours.

description: Travel early in the morning was mostly supportable with a 2 to 4-inch thick melt-freeze crust at the surface. In places, I punched through the crust and it seemed like the crust was breaking down quickly in the morning. By 9 AM on an east-facing slope, ski penetration while skinning was already 4 to 6 inches deep. Below the crust, or what was left of it, is wet snow for the next 10 to 12 inches. The meltwater in this snow is draining (I could feel ice bodies lower in the snowpack) but not quickly enough. In places, I could punch my pole (basket end) deeply into the snowpack.

route: Up Herman Gulch to NE face of the Citadel
description: Moving our way up the NE face when a large loose wet came down the NE Couloir, approx 9 am. No prior evidence of rollerballs on the way up, no cracking, face was in the shade/cloud all morning with reasonable surface winds. Only highlight was fresh overnight snow, approx. 5 inches. Warmer than expected in the valley too.

avalanche_detail.description: There is very little snow in the paths near and above the road. South-facing paths are dry almost to ridgetop. I saw a couple of wet slab avalanches in steep north-facing terrain. I do not know when they ran.

There is very little snow in the paths near and above the road. South-facing paths are dry almost to ridgetop. I saw a couple of wet slab avalanches in steep north-facing terrain. I do not know when they ran.

assets.caption: A couple of recent Wet Slab avalanche in steep, rocky, north-facing terrain in Clear Creek. Photo May 19, 2023
A couple of recent Wet Slab avalanche in steep, rocky, north-facing terrain in Clear Creek. Photo May 19, 2023

avalanche_detail.description: Four new Loose Wet avalanches on the northwest face of Independence Mtn (D1 to 1.5).
Four new Loose Wet avalanches on the northwest face of Independence Mtn (D1 to 1.5).
Four new Loose Wet avalanches on the northwest face of Independence Mtn (D1 to 1.5).

weather_detail.description: Temperatures were just below freezing at 11,500 ft at 8am with mostly clear skies west of the Continental Divide.  However, clouds were parked right on the divide and the sky was mostly cloudy to obscured east of the pass. Clouds started to build by 10 AM and skies were mostly cloudy by 10:30 AM.  Light rain began to fall below 10K ft around this time.

snowpack_detail.description: Surface freeze broke down by 10:30 AM at 11,500 ft but stayed in tact above 12,000 ft.  East-facing terrain around West Roaring Fork north to Geissler Mtn are showing lots of dust.  Other aspects at this elevation are much whiter. Below treeline is draining the abundant melt water effectively.  Only concern would be for heavy rain above 11,500 ft.

Surface freeze broke down by 10:30 AM at 11,500 ft but stayed in tact above 12,000 ft.  East-facing terrain around West Roaring Fork north to Geissler Mtn are showing lots of dust.  Other aspects at this elevation are much whiter. Below treeline is draining the abundant melt water effectively.  Only concern would be for heavy rain above 11,500 ft.

assets.caption: Clouds sat on an east of the Continental Divide, with much clearer skies to the west.  Grizzly Peak is poking through the clouds.  May 19, 2023.
There is still a lot of snow left on the west side of Independed Pass. East-facing slopes are dirtiest, while other aspects are whiter. May 19, 2023
Loose Wet avalanche activity on the northwest face of Independence Mtn.  May 18, 2023

area: Twining Peak- just north of the summit of Independence Pass.
route: Twining Peak from Highway 82.  Up and down south and southwest-facing slopes
objective: Main goal was to confirm we got a good enough freeze for LOW danger.  See if any dry snow  survived above 13K
description: Some new Loose Wet avalanche activity on northwest slopes in the alpine. Decent freeze overnight with a 5cm thick surface crust at 11,500 feet. The crust was 10cm at 12,500 ft, and 20cm thick at 13,500 ft.  There was a think skiff of graupel from yesterday's convective precipitation.

assets.caption: NW face on Mt. Justice pulled out today.  Wet slab R3 D3 in size, narrow at the top going wall to wall in a short distance.  Originated out of a cliff band.

description: Huge avalanche off the NW face of Mt. Justice

assets.caption: E face Torreys
N face Edwards
NE Kelso

route: Torreys- Stevens gulch to tuning fork
description: Solid freeze in the alpine. Winds slowed the thawing despite being hot in between gusts. Once on the ridge, winds were more steady from W-NW. Decended tuning fork at 11:30 with disappointingly frozen conditions for the first 2000ft.

avalanche_detail.description: One new loose wet avalanche above the Upper Lost Man Trailhead and several above Linkin Lake / Geissler Area.  Likely from yesterday afternoon after 1300
One new loose wet avalanche above the Upper Lost Man Trailhead and several above Linkin Lake / Geissler Area.  Likely from yesterday afternoon after 1300

assets.caption: Several wet avalanches above Linkin Lake on Independence Pass probably from ther afternoon of 5/16 (May 17, 2023)
A loose wet avalanche above the Upper Lost Man Trailhead on the edge of the West Roaring Fork Avalanche Area (May 17, 2023)
Another view of the HS-N-D3 on SSE. Likely from the March cycle.
HS-N-D3 on SSE. Likely from the March cycle.

description: Old natural avalanche activity on south aspect of V2

route: Ascended Broken Hand Peak via Broken Dog Leg Couloir at approx 6:30 am. Descended via Broken Hand Pass and observed avalanche at approx 11 am.
description: Wet slide on N facing aspect covered boot pack from my ascent in the morning. Also observed 3 avalanches on E and SE facing aspects in the S Colony Lake cirque.

weather_detail.description: Sunny to Partially Cloudy, 34-40°F, S Face, ≈11,250’, 0-5 mph wind

snowpack_detail.description: Noticed whoopfing, cracks did not propogate more than a skis length. Overnight weak freeze, dropped in around 10am and still wasn’t deteriorated
Noticed whoopfing, cracks did not propogate more than a skis length. Overnight weak freeze, dropped in around 10am and still wasn’t deteriorated

area:
Berthoud Pass, Tea Cup Bowl/Perfect  
Trees, S Face, Near/Below Treeline, ≈11,250’, Sunny to Partially Cloudy, Possibly Triggered by Ski Traverse/Skin Track, 9:00 am picture was taken, unaware of when the slide occurred, noticed whoompfing on the skin up despite overnight weak freeze.

assets.caption: Widespread loose wet avalanches near the summit of Independence Pass.
Numerous wet loose avalanches and a wet slab avalanche in Mountain Boy basin near the top of Independence Pass.

route: Started at current creek Trail head. Headed up and back down the south to south east facing slope. Cut too close to rock band above berthoud pass ditch
description: Wet slide that ran about 100 feet on a South to south west facing slope above Berthoud pass ditch. 35-40 degree slope

avalanche_detail.description: Numerous small avalanches most likely from last weekend as the storm snow warmed.
Numerous small avalanches most likely from last weekend as the storm snow warmed.
Numerous small avalanches most likely from last weekend as the storm snow warmed.

weather_detail.description: Partly cloudy with steady light winds above treeline. Temperatures are warm but nothing out of the ordinary for May.

snowpack_detail.description: The snowpack was supportable to skis with minimal ski penetration at all elevations in the morning. The only exception was heavily treed areas where the ski pen. was much deeper. The surface crust was about 10 cm thick on a north aspect, below treeline, and one-finger hard. Below this was a mostly moist snowpack, 1 meter deep, to the ground. There was a harder (knife-hard) ice lens 25 cm from the surface. This was also found near treeline and it was the harder of the two crusts. Overall the snowpack seems to be draining meltwater from the recent snow. There are places where this meltwater is pooling, such as the knife-hard crust mentioned above, but the water is eventually making its way through and there are no indications that this water pooling will lead to a wet slab issue. Also below treeline, the snowpack is mostly melted in the Fremont Pass area except for northerly slopes.---Near treeline the top foot of snow is mushy but there was no rollerballing even on steep slopes around noon. The snow crystals are already loose, polycrystals, and are no longer precip particles.---Above treeline, the snowpack becomes more supportive. There is dry, pencil-hard, wind-packed snow, beneath surface melt-freeze crusts, and transitioning storm snow, about a foot from the surface at 13k feet. This drier snow does not seem like it is on its way to becoming wet and is not concerning.---On my exit, conditions were still supportive, except below treeline where my skis would sink into the snowpack near any vegetation. Although the snowpack below treeline was becoming less supportive by noon, I did not observe any cracking or collapsing, most likely because the snowpack is draining well.---Overall the most concerning type of terrain would be very steep, sun-exposed, rocky terrain. The snowpack in rocky areas has not recovered to the extent that larger areas open to the sky have.

The surface crust was about 10 cm thick on a north aspect, below treeline, and one-finger hard. Below this was a mostly moist snowpack, 1 meter deep, to the ground. There was a harder (knife-hard) ice lens 25 cm from the surface. This was also found near treeline and it was the harder of the two crusts. Overall the snowpack seems to be draining meltwater from the recent snow. There are places where this meltwater is pooling, such as the knife-hard crust mentioned above, but the water is eventually making its way through and there are no indications that this water pooling will lead to a wet slab issue. Also below treeline, the snowpack is mostly melted in the Fremont Pass area except for northerly slopes.---Near treeline the top foot of snow is mushy but there was no rollerballing even on steep slopes around noon. The snow crystals are already loose, polycrystals, and are no longer precip particles.---Above treeline, the snowpack becomes more supportive. There is dry, pencil-hard, wind-packed snow, beneath surface melt-freeze crusts, and transitioning storm snow, about a foot from the surface at 13k feet. This drier snow does not seem like it is on its way to becoming wet and is not concerning.---On my exit, conditions were still supportive, except below treeline where my skis would sink into the snowpack near any vegetation. Although the snowpack below treeline was becoming less supportive by noon, I did not observe any cracking or collapsing, most likely because the snowpack is draining well.---Overall the most concerning type of terrain would be very steep, sun-exposed, rocky terrain. The snowpack in rocky areas has not recovered to the extent that larger areas open to the sky have.

assets.caption: A quick snowpit on an above treeline, north-facing slope shows a one-finger hard, supportive upper snowpack.
Surface curst on a north-facing below treeline slope at 9 AM.
There is meltwater visible in the top foot of the snowpack below the dusty crust. This melt water is eventually making it's way through a second crust and draining to the ground.
It looked like tough travel conditions a couple of days ago with even snowshoes insufficient for flotation. Conditions were much better today.

area: Mt Arkansas area near Fremont Pass
objective: Look for wet issues. How supportive are crusts? Are wet issues trending better?
description: The new snow from last weekend is transitioning quickly and consolidating with the rest of the snowpack. It is not there yet as melt water is still abundant in the top foot of the snowpack, but it is slowly draining leading to more stable conditions. Clear skies at night are helping with decent freezes of the snow surface despite mild temperatures.

assets.caption: Cornice fall which triggered a wet slab avalanche near the top of Independence Pass.

avalanche_observations.comments: Spring clearing ops and trundling from a D7 produced several gouging loose wet avalanches and one wet slab avalanche below the Waterhole Grade near the summit of Indpendence Pass

assets.caption: Wet avalanches triggered when spring clearing operations trundled snow off of the closed SH82 on Waterhole Grade near the summit of Independence Pass (May 16, 2023)

description: Saw an old wet slab avalanche that ran on the interface between new snow and dust layer. Estimating the avalanche propagated approximately 200 ft across, with a depth up 12”. Likely ran on 5/14. No observed tracks in or out. Most steep gullies facing S, E and W had signs of small WL activity from prior days.

assets.caption: Loose Wet avalanche May 14, 2023
Loose Wet avalanche May 14, 2023
Loose wet natural below storm peak

route: Storm Peak Gnar Couloir via velocity basin.
description: Weak superficial freeze was evident up to 12500 on N to E aspects. Some cold snow held on above 12500 on N. During our descent snow was punchy and rotten around 1pm, observed a small d1r1 natural loose wet slide on a NE at about 12400ft

assets.caption: Slide in Dogleg, S side Loveland pass

route: Toured lower angle slopes S side of Loveland pass in the AM before snow became extremely heavy.
description: Snow started getting heavy early. Snow was shedding pretty much from all steep rocky terrain by the early afternoon. Observed a decent sized slide in Dogleg that started in the upper path. It appears to have stepped down near the dogleg and ran the width of the lower path with a good sized runout. Too many small wet loose slides to count otherwise.
